awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Sustaining Scientific Infrastructure:  Researching Transition from Grants to Peer Production
awd_abstract_narration:
Software is becoming increasingly critical to the activities of science, yet securing long term support for this infrastructure is becoming more challenging. Given constrained budgets, the options for effectively and efficiently supporting sustainable software infrastructure are of growing importance. This project examines the transition of research infrastructure from grant-based funding to long term sustainable models, by examining scientific software projects as they transition to an open source peer production model.  The project tracks software packages as they attempt to transition, and develops a theoretical framework for understanding this process and for explaining their success or failure. The outcome of this research will inform science policy by shaping how the community funds software infrastructure projects in their initial phases, and how to encourage the transition to long-term models thereafter.
 
Inspired by the success of open source software, funding agencies are encouraging transitions to forms of organization that organizational researchers call 'peer production.'  Yet peer production research has shown that simply making code available under an open source license is insufficient to build a motivated and productive community. Successful transition includes changes in team structure (from local to distributed), collaboration technologies (from controlled to open), governance (from hierarchical to shared), and management of participants (from predictable to unpredictable commitment). This project examines successful and unsuccessful transitions from initial grant funding to peer production in scientific software development. Detailed case study histories are developed, by interviewing project participants, funders, and users of scientific software, and by analyzing project archives and software repositories. The research includes six transitioning projects: yt, Enzo, Eclipse PTP, IRODs, Apache OODT and Airavata. In addition, a panel of projects funded by the NSF Software Infrastructure for Sustained Innovation program (which requires plans for sustainability) will be tracked over time to study successful transitions, unsuccessful attempts, and cases where transition was judged inappropriate.  The research is combined with an integrated education plan designed to build organizational skills in the scientific community to enable successful transitions to peer production.

por.por_cntn:
Software is crucial to science, but sustaining projects for long term impact and public availability is challenging. Moving from grants to "the open source way" (more formally called "peer production") is a promising route to sustainability.  Yet much is unknown: we need to know how often transitions are successful, what the challenges are, what researchers need to be successful, and what policies might result in more successfully sustained projects.

We addressed these questions through research, training graduate students, and developing educational resources on transitions to peer production.

We wrote case studies of successful transitions, and we conducted a five-year panel study of 120 projects funded by an NSF program, finding and examining their online presence, publications, code repositories, and interviewing participants. Our key findings were:

1. The 120 grant funded software projects studied were sustained at approximately the same level as the five-year failure rate of venture funded startups (~50%) and at a higher rate than general open-source projects (~15%). This finding shows that science funding for software is undertaking high-risk projects; while not all find a community willing to engage in long term support, many do.

2. Projects were organized in a small set of recognizable organizational forms. We named these: labs, author groups, tool groups, peer production, businesses, and consortia. We described these forms and assessed their different challenges for transition to sustainability.

3. Achieving sustainability by changing the organization of scientific software projects was relatively rare. For example, we saw only one traditional single-PI lab moving to peer production; almost all projects organized as labs remained labs.  We conclude that organizational change is difficult and likely requires specific support and training.

4. The most common route to peer production sustainability was beginning with peer production (14 of the 24 projects ending in peer production). This result is consistent with the challenges of change. Transitions to peer production were also achieved through hand-offs (funding projects with existing connections to peer production projects to which they handed off code during or just after the grant funding period). We conclude that funding aiming at sustainability should specifically call for collaborations with existing peer production projects and value evidence of existing connections between PIs and these projects.

Our interviews with participants provided insight into challenges faced, including relatively small potential contributor communities, the difficulty of mentoring potential contributors, and the challenge of identifying next generations of leaders. Key practices associated with sustainability included existing engagement with peer production communities and the long-term presence of scientific staff responsible for packages, including mentoring contributions.

Our case studies describe routes to peer production, giving detail from which other projects can learn.  A key result for the case of Enzo (an astronomy package) was the importance of faculty startup funds used to merge forks resulting from a diaspora of Enzo user-developers; an event called the "week of code." In addition, our cases highlight the importance?and the difficulty?of generational succession. We identify these sort of diaspora-merging events, together with finding new "generations" of leaders, as a potentially lower-cost but high impact grant funding opportunity.

We provided education for graduate students in the information sciences and training for scientific software developers. The project directly involved three doctoral students in the research and a masters student who has since gone on to doctoral study.  One doctoral student on the project has developed a related dissertation and in her final year was invited to co-organize a practitioner-focused workshop on scientific software work and to give a keynote at a funding agency workshop. We developed a semester-long course on peer production, published openly on github. The course is sociotechnical; pairing social science theory (e.g. coordination) with technical skills focused on git-based software collaboration (e.g., "git merge").

We developed and delivered materials focused on key challenges for scientific software development students, including tutorials on splitting github pull requests into separate tasks. Potential contributors can be discouraged because they don?t know how to do this, and the process can be costly for developers to mentor contributors through. We also developed github based scenarios for small groups of students to simulate participation in projects.

As a result of the research and education funded by this grant, we have a clearer idea of the way that software in science is developed, how projects are organized, how they change (or do not) and how they might be more successful in transitioning from grant-funding to vibrant, open projects building software available to other researchers and to the public.
